questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was diagnosed with mesenteric ischemia and has undergone massive small bowel resection for the gangrenous segment. The patient is now on parenteral feeding. Which of the following is the most common complication of TPN?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Catheter-related complications Complications are associated with central venous catheters, including those associated with catheter insertion and immediate access-related issues, as well as longer-term (>1 week) complications: Immediate risks of peripherally inserted catheters include injury to local structures, phlebitis at the insertion site, air embolism, hematoma, arrhythmia, and catheter malposition. Late complications include infection, thrombosis, and catheter malposition. The number and severity of complications increase with catheter size, multiple catheter implantations, and a longer catheter dwelling time. Catheters can also get mispositioned and catheter-induced infection may also develop.

questions.text: A 55 years old female patient has undergone Puestow’s procedure for chronic pancreatitis. Which is the most preferred route for supplementary nutrition in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Feeding jejunostomy A feeding jejunostomy is the preferred procedure to provide supplementary nutrition in this patient as it provides protection to the pancreatic anastomosis and causes minimal stimulation of pancreatic secretion thereby giving rest to the pancreas. A feeding jejunostomy is a mode of enteral nutrition in patients who can’t take it orally.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. TPN: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is a method of feeding that bypasses the gastrointestinal tract . Fluids are given into a vein to provide most of the nutrients the body needs. The method is used when a person cannot or should not receive feedings or fluids by mouth. Option: B. Pancreatic surgery does not usually interfere with the function of the gastrointestinal tract and enteral route. After pancreatic surgery, TPN should or only be used when there is intolerance to enteral nutrition or enteral nutrition is contraindicated. Option: C. Feeding Gastrostomy: Gastrostomy is used to provide a route for tube feeding if needed for four weeks or longer, and/or to vent the stomach for air or drainage. Disadvantages of gastrostomy feeding include the surgery required to place the tube, possible skin irritation or infection around the gastrostomy site, increased incidence of nausea and vomiting , increased incidence of aspiration pneumonia due to gastroesophageal reflux and a slight risk of intra-abdominal leakage resulting in peritonitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with refeeding syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperkalemia Diagnosis of Refeeding syndrome is done with low levels of phosphate, potassium, calcium, and magnesium and lactic acidosis . Hence, Option(C) Hyperkalemia is not associated with refeeding syndrome.

Highyeild:

Refeeding Syndrome: One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding is refeeding syndrome This occurs in the first days after feeding i s commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished. Pathology: Hypophosphataemia , resulting in fluid and electrolyte shifts between the intra- and extracellular compartments. Clinical Features: Arrhythmias, muscle weakness, respiratory or cardiac failure, edema, lethargy, or seizures; at its most severe the syndrome can be fatal Diagnosis: Low levels of phosphate, potassium, calcium, and magnesium, and a lactic acidosis Refeeding syndrome The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER One or more of the following: BMI <16 kg/m² Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days Low potassium, phosphate, or magnesium levels before feeding OR Two or more of the following: BMI <18.5 kg/m² Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3–6 months Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids, or diuretics Management: Nutritional Support Started at a maximum of 10 kcal/kg per day, aiming to increase levels slowly to meet full needs by 4–7 days Frequent monitoring and replacement of the electrolytes Supplementary thiamine, vitamin B, multivitamins, and trace elements.

questions.text: Which of the following is a metabolic response to starvation?
questions.correct_answer: B. Reduction in resting energy expenditure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduction in resting energy expenditure Resting energy expenditure levels significantly decrease in starvation, related in part to reduced conversion of inactive thyroxine (T4) to active tri-iodothyronine (T3). Nevertheless, this reduction is insufficient to obviate the need for metabolic substrates, leaving a glucose requirement of approximately 200 g per day even during conditions of prolonged fasting

Highyeild:

Short-term Fasting: Insulin levels fall and glucagon levels rise, glycogenolysis is the main source of glucose, whereby glycogen stores from the liver and skeletal muscle are converted to glucose via lactate (the Cori cycle) 24-40 Hours Fasting: Glycogen reserves are depleted and gluconeogenesis (the de novo synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as the amino acids glutamine and alanine, as well as fructose Prolonged Fasting (>48 hours): glucose production is met by the breakdown of fat stores (lipolysis) ; this provides glycerol, which is then converted to fatty acids and glucose Metabolic response to starvation Low plasma insulin High plasma glucagon Hepatic glycogenolysis Protein catabolism Hepatic gluconeogenesis Lipolysis: Mobilization of fat stores (increased fat oxidation) – overall decrease in protein and carbohydrate oxidation Adaptive ketogenesis Reduction in resting energy expenditure (from approximately 25–30 kcal/kg per day to 15–20 kcal/kg per day

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Adaptive Ketogenesis - Fatty acids can be converted to ketones , which can be used as a metabolic substrate by the majority of tissues in circumstances of extended fasting, reducing the need for muscle breakdown Option: C. Protein catabolism happens in metabolic response to starvation. The generation of amino acids occurs from the catabolism of skeletal muscle, in amounts of up to 75 g per day for the average-sized individual. Option: D. Low plasma Insulin - During short-term fasting periods, when insulin levels fall and glucagon levels rise , glycogenolysis is the main source of glucose, whereby glycogen stores from the liver and skeletal muscle are converted to glucose via lactate (the Cori cycle)

questions.text: Which of the following is a metabolic response to trauma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased Glucagon The metabolic response to trauma is influenced by the early and rapid rises in sympathetic nervous system activity and circulating catecholamines and elevated levels of glucocorticoids, glucagon, and growth hormone, as well as insulin

Highyeild:

The neuroendocrine response to severe injury/critical illness is biphasic: The acute phase (hours) is characterized by elevated counterregulatory hormones (cortisol, glucagon, adrenaline). Changes are thought to be beneficial for short-term survival Chronic phase (days) associated with hypothalamic suppression and low serum levels of the respective target organ hormones. Changes may contribute to chronic wasting Metabolic Response to Trauma Two Phases Catabolic Phase : Hypovolaemia, decreased basal metabolic rate, reduced cardiac output, hypothermia, and lactic acidosis Hormones regulating the catabolic phase are catecholamines, cortisol, and aldosterone (following activation of the renin-angiotensin system), and inflammatory cytokines (e.g. IL-1, IL-6, and TNFα) result in significant fat and protein mobilization, leading to significant weight loss and increased urinary nitrogen excretion Hypermetabolic Phase: Characterized by tissue edema (from vasodilatation and increased capillary leakage), increased basal metabolic rate (hypermetabolism), increased cardiac output, raised body temperature, leukocytosis, increased oxygen consumption, and increased gluconeogenesis The combination of pronounced or prolonged catabolism in association with insulin resistance places patients within this phase at increased risk of septic and other complications

questions.text: Which among the following is an absolute contraindication for feeding jejunostomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distal Intestinal Obstruction The only absolute contraindication to feeding jejunostomy is distal intestinal obstruction. Relative contraindications include severe edema of the intestinal wall, radiation enteritis, inflammatory bowel disease, ascites, severe immunodeficiency, and bowel ischemia .

questions.text: Choose the correct option with regards to insertion complication of Parenteral Feeding. The most common complication of line insertion is an inadvertent pneumothorax, most commonly during the insertion of cephalic lines The line is considered to be in the wrong place if the tip is at the aortocaval junction It is managed by the insertion of a chest drain, which can be removed once the pneumothorax has resolved Select the correct answer from given below options:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

False, False, True The most common complication of line insertion is an inadvertent pneumothorax , which occurs in around 0.5–1% of cases, most commonly during the insertion of subclavian lines. It is managed by the insertion of a chest drain, which can be removed once the pneumothorax has resolved . Line misplacement can also occur and is diagnosed on a chest radiograph, which is mandatory following central line insertion. The line is considered to be in the correct place if the tip is in the inferior third of the SVC or at the aortocaval junction
